sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

note.p: Friend and correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Novelist and writer of children's books popular in England and America. Her early texts were published anonymously, while the majority were published as the work of Mrs. Hofland.

Barbara Hofland was born in 1770 in Sheffield, Yorkshire. She was daughter of Robert Wreaks, a Sheffield manufacturer, and Barbara Clark; her father died when she was three. She published poems from July 1794 in the local newspaper, The Sheffield Iris and also started a milliner's shop, before her marriage to Thomas Bradshawe Hoole on June 25, 1796 at Bath. They had two children, Frederic Parkyn Hoole (1796-1833) and a daughter who died in infancy. She was left a widow upon her husband's death on 1798, after only two years of marriage. After the failure of her husband's firm and other financial reverses, she went to live with her mother-in-law in Attercliffe, Sheffield. In 1805, she published The Poems of Barbara Hoole by subscription, with the help of James Montgomery. In 1809 she opened and ran a girls' school at Grove House, Harrogate, and also published her first children's story, History of an Officer's Widow.

She married artist Thomas Christopher Hofland on January 28, 1810 at Knaresborough, Yorkshire, near Leeds; shortly thereafter, they moved to London and lived at Newman Street; they also lived at 2 Ormond Road in Richmond and in 1840 and 1841 historical records indicate their address is Bradmore House, Queen Street, Hammersmith. They had one child, Thomas R. Hofland. She died on 4 November 1843 in Richmond.

At the request of George Spencer-Churchill, the sixth Duke of Marlborough, he and Barbara Hofland produced a lavish book of engravings of Whiteknights, the Duke's estate in Berkshire, entitled: A Descriptive Account of the Mansion and Gardens of White-Knights: A Seat of His Grace the Duke of Marlborough. By Mrs. Hofland. Illustrated with twenty-three engravings, from pictures taken on the spot by T.C. Hofland. Mitford suggests that the Hoflands supported the entire cost of engraving and printing themselves and printed only fifty copies, because the bankrupt Duke could not finance the venture. In a February 27, 1819 letter to Sir William Elford,Mitford indicates that she does not expect him to buy a copy of the book, since he is a great deal too wise to deal in books printed upon drawing paper in Atlas quarto—books merely meant to make a show. It is unknown how many copies were sold.

Thomas Hofland was born on 12 December 1777, the son of a Worksop, Nottinghamshire manufacturer. He became a painter, mainly known for landscape paintings of the Lake District and the area around his home in Richmond. He studied under John Rathbone and exhibited at the Royal Academy between 1799 and 1805. He later worked as a botanical illustrator at Kew and exhibited at the Leeds Gallery. He was the second husband of the author Barbara Hofland.

They married on 28 Jan 1810 at Knaresborough, Yorkshire, near Leeds; shortly thereafter, they moved to London and lived at Newman Street; they also lived at 2 Ormond Road in Richmond and in 1840 and 1841 historical records indicate their address is Bradmore House, Queen Street, Hammersmith. They had one child, Thomas R. Hofland.

Hofland earned his living as an artist largely from teaching painting and from copying works from the British Institution (now the British Museum), while continuing to paint original landscapes. He was one of the founders of the Society of British Artists. Some of his best-known works are two painted in 1814: A Storm Off Scarborough, which won the British Institution prize in 1814; and A View from Richmond Hill, which was engraved by Heath in 1823. Other notable works include Windsor Castle by Moonlight, Llanberris Lake, and View of Windermere.

At the request of George Spencer-Churchill, the sixth Duke of Marlborough, he and Barbara Hofland produced a lavish book of engravings of Whiteknights, the Duke's estate in Berkshire, entitled: A Descriptive Account of the Mansion and Gardens of White-Knights: A Seat of His Grace the Duke of Marlborough. By Mrs. Hofland. Illustrated with twenty-three engravings, from pictures taken on the spot by T.C. Hofland. Mitford suggests that Hoflands supported the entire cost of engraving and printing themselves and printed only fifty copies, because the bankrupt Duke could not finance the venture. In a February 27, 1819 letter to Sir William Elford,Mitford indicates that she does not expect him to buy a copy of the book, since he is "a great deal too wise to deal in books printed upon drawing paper in Atlas quarto--books merely meant to make a show." It is unknown how many copies were sold. In 1838, Hofland produced The British Angler's Manual, an illustrated guide to angling, fishing, and trolling. He died on 3 January 1843 of cancer at Leamington Spa, where he had gone for his health. SOURCE: ODNB.

person.note: Benjamin Robert Haydon was a painter educated at the Royal Academy, who was famous for contemporary, historical, classical, biblical, and mythological scenes, though tormented by financial difficulties and incarceration. He painted William Wordsworth's portrait in 1842 and painted a cameo of Keats in his epic canvas Christ's Entry into Jerusalem(1814-20). MRM was introduced to him at his London studio in the spring of 1817, and Sir William Elford was a mutual friend, and Haydon's own acquaintances included several prominent British Romantic literary figures. He completed "The Raising of Lazarus" in 1823. He wrote a diary and an autobiography, both of which were published only posthumously, and he committed suicide in 1846. George Paston's Little Memoirs of the Nineteenth Century (1893) contends that Mitford was asked to edit Haydon's memoir, but declined.

person.persName: Benjamin Robert Haydon Haydon Robert Benjamin
person.note: Benjamin Robert Haydon (the first of that name) was the father of painter Benjamin Robert Haydon; he was a printer, publisher, and bookseller in Devon. Source: ODNB.

Sarah Cobley Haydon was the mother of painter Benjamin Robert Haydon. She was the daughter of the Rev. Benjamin Cobley, curate of Shillingford and later Rector of Dodbrooke, Kingsbridge, Devon. Source: ODNB.
Mary Cawse Hyman was was a widow with two children when she married Benjamin Robert Haydon on 10 October 1821.

J. B. (John Berkeley) Monck was a Whig Member of Parliament for Reading, from 1820 to 1830, and he frequently franked Mary Russell Mitford's letters. Mitford's letter to Sir William Elford of 20 March 1820 describes the election of Monck, describing him in context with a shoemaker who brought him from France: Mr. Monck an opposition man of large fortune brought from France in a fit of patriotism by our celebrated shoemaker & Patriot Mr. Warry. Monck was also the author of General Reflections on the System of the Poor Laws (1807), in which he argued for a gradual approach to abolishing the Poor Laws, and for the reform of workhouses. Dr. Webb's research suggests that celebrated shoemaker is Mr. Warry, possibly Joseph John Berkeley (J.B.) Monck was the spouse of Mary Stephens Monck; they married on 4 May 1810 at Aldermaston. Together they had four children: John Bligh, Emilia, Mariette, and William Stanley. They lived together at Coley Park, a large estate purchased in the parish of St. Mary's, near Reading, until John Berkeley Monck's death in 1834; his son John Bligh inherited the estate. Francis Needham claims that it is J. B. and his wife Mary who are referred to in Violeting, when the narrator thinks she sees Mr. and Mrs. M. and dear B.. (Dear B. would be their son, Bligh.) Source: Francis Needham, Letter to William Roberts, 26 March 1954. Needham Papers, Reading Central Library.

Mary Stephens Monck was the spouse of John Berkeley Monck; they married on 4 May 1810 at Aldermaston. Together they had four children: John Bligh, Emilia, Mariette, and William Stanley. They lived together at Coley Park in the parish of St. Mary's, near Reading, until John Berkeley Monck's death in 1834. She later lived with her daughter Emilia at The Rectory, Caversham, Oxfordshire. Francis Needham claims that it is she and her husband who are referred to in Violeting, when the narrator thinks she sees Mr. and Mrs. M. and dear B.. (Dear B. would be their son, Bligh.) Source: Francis Needham, Letter to William Roberts, 26 March, 1954. Needham Papers, Reading Central Library.

birth.placeName: Coley Park, parish of St. Mary's, Reading, Berkshire, England

person.death: Coley Park, parish of St. Mary's, Reading, Berkshire, England
person.note: Eldest son of John Berkeley Monck and Mary Stephens Monck. He inherited the Coley Park estate on his father's death in 1834 and he lived there with his wife and children until his death in 1903. Francis Needham claims that it is John B. Monck, his wife Mary, and their son John Bligh who are referred to in Violeting, when the narrator thinks she sees Mr. and Mrs. M. and dear B.. (Dear B. would be their son, Bligh.) Source: Francis Needham, Letter to William Roberts, 26 March, 1954. Needham Papers, Reading Central Library.
Rachel, his eldest daughter, married Sir Thomas Noon Talfourd.
She's the eldest daughter of John Rutt.

note.p: British author and jurist (26 May 1795-13 Mar. 1854) Born in Reading, Berkshire; died while serving in the Court of Stafford in 1854. Charles Dickens dedicated The Pickwick Papers to Talfourd. Talfourd’s best-known works include his plays Ion (1835), The Athenian Captive (1837) and Glencoe, or the Fate of the MacDonalds (1839). Friend, mentor, and frequent correspondent with Mitford.
